text.headline: Hidden Geographies of AI
text.text:
Behind every AI model, every smartphone, every data center lies a hidden geography of extraction, labor, and environmental impact that spans the globe.

This story reveals the true cost of artificial intelligence: how resources flow from the Global South to power innovation concentrated in the Global North.

text.headline: The Rare Earth Foundation
text.text:
Bayan Obo Mine, China

Deep in Inner Mongolia lies the world's largest rare earth mine, producing 45,000 tons annually of neodymium, dysprosium, and yttrium - essential elements in every AI chip and smartphone.

üè≠ Production: 45,000 MT annually
üë• Workers: 25,000
üí∞ Avg. Wage: $400/month
üåç Environmental Impact: 10/10 - Radioactive contamination

The rare earth elements extracted here form the backbone of global AI infrastructure, yet the environmental and health costs remain largely invisible to end users.

text.headline: The Shadow Supply Chain
text.text:
Myanmar Kachin State

In Myanmar's conflict zones, military-controlled mining operations extract rare earth elements under conditions of extreme violence and environmental destruction.

üè≠ Production: 31,000 MT annually
üë• Workers: 50,000
üí∞ Avg. Wage: $150/month
üåç Environmental Impact: 10/10 - Toxic exposure, deaths reported

Global Witness reports that Chinese-backed operations have led to toxic exposure and death among local communities. This represents the darkest edge of AI's supply chain.

media.caption: Myanmar rare earth mining - extraction under military control

text.headline: The Cobalt Crisis
text.text:
Kolwezi Mining District, Democratic Republic of Congo

The world's largest cobalt mining district, producing 84,000 tons annually - 70% of global supply. Cobalt is essential for the lithium-ion batteries that power AI data centers and devices.

üè≠ Production: 84,000 MT annually
üë• Workers: 40,000
üí∞ Avg. Wage: $50/month
üåç Environmental Impact: 10/10 - Child labor, water contamination

Amnesty International and other organizations have documented widespread child labor, with children as young as 7 working in dangerous conditions to extract cobalt for tech companies.

media.caption: Kolwezi cobalt mines - child labor in AI's supply chain

text.headline: The Lithium Triangle
text.text:
Salar de Uyuni, Bolivia

The world's largest lithium reserve sits beneath Bolivia's salt flats. With 23 million tons of lithium reserves, this site could power the battery revolution - but at what cost to indigenous communities?

üè≠ Reserves: 23 million MT
üë• Workers: 2,000
üí∞ Avg. Wage: $800/month
üåç Environmental Impact: 7/10 - Indigenous displacement

Lithium extraction threatens traditional ways of life for indigenous communities who have lived on these lands for centuries, while the extracted lithium powers AI data centers thousands of miles away.

media.caption: Salar de Uyuni - lithium extraction from indigenous lands

text.headline: Digital Labor in the Shadows
text.text:
Nairobi, Kenya

While Silicon Valley develops AI, thousands of Kenyan workers moderate content and label data for tech giants. This invisible workforce trains the algorithms that will automate their own jobs.

üë• Workers: 40,000
üí∞ Avg. Wage: $65/month
üß† Work: Content moderation, data labeling
‚ö†Ô∏è Impact: Mental health trauma, job insecurity

CBS News' 60 Minutes investigation revealed that workers face traumatic content daily while earning a fraction of Silicon Valley wages for the same companies.

media.caption: Nairobi content moderation centers - the hidden human workforce behind AI

text.headline: The Data Assembly Line
text.text:
Bangalore, India

India's tech capital houses 250,000 digital workers who annotate data, moderate content, and train AI systems. This massive workforce forms the invisible backbone of machine learning.

üë• Workers: 250,000
üí∞ Avg. Wage: $350/month
üß† Work: Data annotation, AI training
üè¢ Companies: Amazon, iMerit, Clickworker

Gray & Suri's research shows how this 'ghost work' - invisible, on-demand labor - makes AI possible while keeping workers in precarious conditions.

media.caption: Bangalore data centers - the ghost workers training AI

text.headline: The Innovation Concentration
text.text:
Silicon Valley, United States

Here, extracted materials and digital labor converge into AI innovation. While representing less than 1% of global population, Silicon Valley captures the majority of AI's economic value.

üë• Workers: 500,000
üí∞ Avg. Wage: $18,000/month
üè¢ Companies: Google, Meta, OpenAI
üí° Focus: AI research and development

The wage gap is stark: Silicon Valley AI workers earn 277x more than cobalt miners in DRC, yet both are essential to the same technological ecosystem.

media.caption: Silicon Valley - where extracted value concentrates into AI innovation

text.headline: The Energy Infrastructure
text.text:
Northern Virginia, United States

The world's largest concentration of data centers powers AI training and inference. These facilities consume more electricity than entire countries, requiring massive energy infrastructure.

‚ö° Capacity: 1,799 MW
üë• Workers: 25,000
üí∞ Avg. Wage: $8,000/month
üåç Environmental Impact: 7/10 - Massive energy consumption

Each AI training run can consume as much electricity as 100 homes use in a year, highlighting the environmental cost of artificial intelligence.

media.caption: Northern Virginia data centers - the energy infrastructure powering AI

text.headline: The True Cost
text.text:
Global Impact Assessment

The hidden geographies of AI reveal profound inequalities:

  • Environmental: Mining operations score 8-10/10 on environmental impact
  • Labor: 277x wage gap between extraction and innovation
  • Geographic: Value extraction from Global South, capture in Global North
  • Social: Child labor, displacement, health impacts

This map represents more than technology - it shows how AI development perpetuates global inequalities while concentrating benefits among the already privileged.

media.caption: The global geography of AI's hidden costs

text.headline: Toward Equitable AI
text.text:
Lessons from the Margins

Communities across the Global South are developing counter-hegemonic responses to AI extraction:

  • Community-controlled mining: Indigenous groups asserting resource sovereignty
  • Platform cooperatives: Worker-owned alternatives to exploitative digital labor
  • Local AI development: Context-appropriate technology for community needs
  • Environmental justice: Movements demanding cleanup and reparations

The future of AI depends on learning from these voices from the margins and building more equitable technological systems.

This research contributes to ongoing efforts to center Global South perspectives in AI governance and policy discussions.
